chapter.tagline: Exploring the dimensions of the believer’s walk—how to express the new life in daily conduct and purpose.

questions.q: What does it mean to 'walk' in Scripture?
questions.a: In Greek, 'walk' speaks of consistent lifestyle or manner of living. To walk in the Spirit means to habitually conduct life according to the new nature within.

questions.q: What is the difference between Peripateo and Stoicheo?
questions.a: Peripateo means general conduct in life; Stoicheo means keeping in step with divine order. Peripateo is living; Stoicheo is aligning that living with God’s rhythm.
Emperipateo depicts walking around within divine boundaries—living fully conscious of God’s presence everywhere you go.

questions.q: What does Orthopodeo mean in Galatians 2:14?
questions.a: Orthopodeo means walking straight or uprightly according to the truth of the gospel. It’s maintaining doctrinal accuracy and moral consistency.
Poreuomai carries the idea of purposeful journeying—living with divine direction, not wandering aimlessly. Every step is toward destiny.

questions.q: How does one walk worthy of the Lord?
questions.a: By letting inner realities govern outward actions—expressing love, humility, and obedience as fruits of the Spirit, not human effort.

questions.q: Can a believer walk in the flesh and still be spiritual?
questions.a: No. To walk in the flesh is to depend on self; to walk in the Spirit is to depend on Christ within. They are mutually exclusive patterns of life.
Grace. The same power that raised Christ enables daily living. The Spirit energizes the believer’s will and emotions to manifest divine conduct.

questions.q: Why are there many Greek words for 'walk'?
questions.a: Because walking in Christ is multidimensional—character, doctrine, fellowship, and mission. Each term highlights a unique expression of divine life.

questions.q: How does right walking glorify God?
questions.a: When believers express Christ’s nature visibly, the world sees the invisible God. Walking rightly is evangelism in motion.
